tls.check_trust_prompt.en: Do you trust any of these certificate authorities?
tls.check_trust_prompt.en-tts: Do you trust any of these certificate authorities?

tls.cmd_help.en:
Establishing an encrypted tls connection requires the host to provide a signed Certificate of identity. Each Certificate is signed for authenticity by a Certificate Authority. The CA's Certificate will in-turn be signed by yet another CA. These signed Certificates link into a chain of trust back to a trusted Root CA.

Typically, this all happens automagically because many OS's & browsers incorporate a long list of trusted Root CA Certiicates. And this is OK because you trust the CA's that your OS trusts, right!

On Precursor, you must explicitly trust one or more root CA Certificates. You can:
net tls probe <host>
	to trust a specific CA Certificate, or
net tls mozilla
	to trust all of the CA Certificates incporporated in the Firefox browser.

The CA's Certificate will in-turn be signed by yet another CA. These signed Certificates link into a chain of trust back to a trusted Root CA.

Typically, this all happens automagically because many OS's & browsers incorporate a long list of trusted Root CA Certiicates. And this is OK because you trust the CA's that your OS trusts, right!

On Precursor, you must explicitly trust one or more root CA Certificates. You can:
net tls probe <host>
	to trust a specific CA Certificate, or

tls.mozilla_cmd.en: trust all Root CA's in webpki-roots
tls.mozilla_cmd.en-tts: trust all Root CA's in webpki-roots
